inlineContent.text: Use any of the 25 semantic convenience cases or array
expressible syntax including offsets as applicable.
As an alternative to offsets, use prefix/postfix “shift”
operators +/- to further offset the point by 0.125 –
effectively increasing the amount of relative points on
the rectangle to 121. Use prefix +/- to offset columns,
Use .point(on/from) methods to convert a relative
point to a real point (on a size, or from a rect).
Example Quadrantals as a series of points for a path:
regular   with offset    custom point  col shift  row shift
To specify points outside of the rectangle use
column Z or F or rows 0 or 6 respectively, increasing
the number of relative points on a rectangle to 225.
Advanced: Quadrantals also support specifying points
with bezier control points to create cubic bezier curves.
two control points at C1 and A5 respectively.
If the second control point is nil it is the same as the first.

abstract.text: is a
position unit based
on decimal units between 0.0 and 1.0 for each
axis, represented by 25 points on a rectangle
with 5 columns and 5 rows.
Associate an END cubic bezier control point with a quadrantal.
e.g. .A2 *– .C3 (“A2” is the control point). This is the “end”
control point because in a curve, the quadrantal is the “end point”
which the control point comes off of to complete the curve.
Subtract an
point offset from a quadrantal.
Add a
offset to a quadrantal.
The offset must be expressed in unit points ~0.0 -> ~1.0
Example: .A3 + [0.1,0]
This offset does not affect existing control points.
Shift a quadrantal horizontally by a relative amount that is
exactly half the distance between two quadrantals: -0.125.
This operator is placed
the quadrantal as it relates
to the column. Example: -.B1 shifts the quadrantal to exactly
between “A” and “B”.
Is the position layout sensitive.
i.e. is it on the horizontal axis
and not horizontal center.
Shift a quadrantal vertically by a relative amount that is
exactly half the distance between two quadrantals: +0.125.
This operator is placed
the quadrantal as it relates
to the row. Example: .A1+ shifts the quadrantal to exactly
between rows “1” and “2”.
Associate a right-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the right-side will “mirror” the left-side along the
axis.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: 1.5 -== .C3 –* .A5
Shift a quadrantal horizontally by a relative amount that is
exactly half the distance between two quadrantals: +0.125.
This operator is placed
the quadrantal as it relates
to the column. Example: +.A1 shifts the quadrantal to exactly
between “A” and “B”.
is a
position unit based
on decimal units between 0.0 and 1.0 for each
axis, represented by 25 points on a rectangle
with 5 columns and 5 rows.
Subtract a
offset from a quadrantal.
The offset must be expressed in unit points ~0.0 -> ~1.0
Example: .A3 - [0.1,0]
This offset does not affect existing control points.
Associate a right-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the right-side will “mirror” the left-side along the
axis.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: 1.5 |== .C3 –* .A5
Convert this Quadrantal to a Position
Associate a right-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the right-side will be on the same tangent as the
left-side enabling
creation of consistent and smooth curves.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: .C3
For internal use only.
is a Swift framework for developing apps on iOS and iPadOS.
Relative point
offset.
Associate a left-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the left-side will “mirror” the right-side along the
axis.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: .A4 *– .C3 ==- 1.5
Was this relative position specified using literal values
(e.g. [0.5,0.5]) or named values (e.g. .center or .C3).
Create a new layout Quadrantal with relative x and y values
and optional absolute point offset.
Prefer other means of initializating Quadrantal if possible.
Associate a left-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the left-side will “mirror” the right-side along the
axis.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: .A4 *– .C3 ==| 1.5
Associate a right-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle is exactly the same as the
control point, creating
a
point.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: 1.5 <== .C3 –* .A5
Any relatively defined shape that can be re-oriented
by altering its relative points, either relative to
a “base edge”, by “turning” the point values, or
“flipping” them.
Associate a START cubic bezier control point with a quadrantal.
e.g. .C3 –* .A2 (“A2” is the control point). This is the “start”
control point because in a curve, the quadrantal point here will
become the start point for the
curve from which this control
point emanates from.
Absolute point offsets.
Element that can have an x and y coordinate in points.
Shift a quadrantal vertically by a relative amount that is
exactly half the distance between two quadrantals: -0.125.
This operator is placed
the quadrantal as it relates
to the row. Example: .B1- shifts the quadrantal to exactly
between rows “1” and “2”.
Associate a left-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle and length is synchronized with the
control
point, such that the left-side will be on the same tangent as the
right-side enabling
creation of consistent and smooth curves.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: 0.5
Container for options and enumerations that are
used for layout in this framework.
Does this relative position have bezier control points.
Add an
point offset to a quadrantal.
Associate a left-side bezier control point with a quadrantal, so that
it’s angle is exactly the same as the
control point, creating
a
point.
Length is a relative percentage of the existing control point, with 1.0
matching the length, 0.5 half the length, 2.0 doubling the length, etc.
Example: .A5 *– .C3 ==> 1.5
A value item that represents a relative
(vs. absolute) position in layout.
